html:
Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈru.oː/, [ˈrʊ.oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈru.o/, [ˈruː.ɔ]

Etymology 1[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *h₃rew- . Cognate with Ancient Greek ὀρούω (oroúō, “hurry”).

Verb[edit]

ruō (present infinitive ruere, perfect active ruī, supine rutum); third conjugation

  1. I hurry, rush, hasten, move quickly.
  2. I collapse, fall down.
  3. I fail, fall.
  4. I cast down; I hurl to the ground.

Derived terms[edit]
  • arruō
  • corruō
  • diruō
  • irruō
  • obruō
  • ruīna
  • surruō
Descendants[edit]
  • English: ruin
  • French: ruer
  • Portuguese: ruir
  • Spanish: ruir
  • Sardinian: ruere, Sardinian: arrui

Etymology 2[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *(H)rewH- (“to tear out, dig out”).

Verb[edit]

ruō (present infinitive ruere); third conjugation, no perfect or supine stem

  1. I dig out

Derived terms[edit]

Usage notes[edit]

There has been some confusion between the derivatives of the two verbs.

References[edit]

  • ruo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
